DataElement.preferredName: Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma Transplantation Time Partial Remission Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A description of the type of partial remission of the non-hodgkin lymphoma at the time of transplant.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma Transplantation Time Partial Remission
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Distinct from Hodgkin lymphoma both morphologically and biologically, Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) is characterized by the absence of Reed-Sternberg cells, can occur at any age, and usually presents as a localized or generalized lymphadenopathy associated with fever and weight loss.  The clinical course varies according to the morphologic type.  NHL is clinically classified as indolent, aggressive, or having a variable clinical course.  NHL can be of B-or T-/NK-cell lineage._The grafting of tissues from one individual to another or place to place within a single individual._The continuum of experience in which events pass from the future through the present to the past._A decrease in the size of a tumor, or in the extent of cancer in the body, in response to treatment.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Distinct from Hodgkin's lymphoma both morphologically and biologically, NHL lymphoma is characterized by the absence of Reed-Sternberg cells, can occur at any age, and usually presents as a localized or generalized lymphadenopathy associated with fever and weight loss.  The clinical course varies according to the morphologic type.  NHL is clinically classified as indolent, aggressive, or having a variable clinical course.  NHL can be of B-or T-/NK-cell lineage. --2003

Concepts.definition: Distinct from Hodgkin lymphoma both morphologically and biologically, non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) is characterized by the absence of Reed-Sternberg cells, can occur at any age, and usually presents as a localized or generalized lymphadenopathy associated with fever and weight loss. The clinical course varies according to the morphologic type. NHL is clinically classified as indolent, aggressive, or having a variable clinical course. NHL can be of B-or T-/NK-cell lineage.

Concepts.definition: Transference of a tissue or organ within an individual, between individuals of the same species, or between individuals of different species.
The continuum of experience in which events pass from the future through the present to the past.
A finding indicating that there is a decrease in the size and the extent of tissue involvement by a malignant tumor in a patient.
